subject: Travel
subcategory: The Story of Maps and Navigation
title: The Longitude Problem
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The Longitude Problem.

hook.text: For centuries, sailors could measure latitude easily but longitude was impossible. Ships wrecked by the thousands.

buildup.text: In 1707, four British warships hit rocks off the Scilly Isles because they couldn't calculate their position.

discovery.text: Britain offered a Â£20,000 prize for solving longitude. The greatest scientists in Europe competed.

twist.text: A self-taught carpenter named John Harrison solved it with a clock, not astronomy. The committee refused to pay.

climax.text: Harrison's marine chronometer kept perfect time at sea. King George III intervened and forced payment.

punchline.text: A carpenter beat the world's best scientists with a clock.

quiz.question: How did John Harrison solve the longitude problem?
options: With a new type of compass
